etymologies: early 19th century; earliest use found in Aberdeen Journal. Probably from grand + drill, in which case some forms probably show alteration by association with words in -elle

definitions: A mottled yarn which is plied with two different colours of thread; (also) an (especially cotton) cloth made from a warp of such yarn and a plain-coloured weft, used especially for making shirts or trousers.
Of a yarn, twist, or item of clothing: made of grandrelle.
